title: Booth
author: Fowler, Karen Joy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read Booth over the course of a few days; usually a book like this would take me weeks. I simply didn’t expect a 469 page historical novel to hold mI read Booth over the course of a few days; usually a book like this would take me weeks. I simply didn’t expect a 469 page historical novel to hold me in such a tight grip.Historical facts are historical facts (who went where and why); it’s Fowler’s attention to detail and exquisite prose that make the book an experience. A trip across the Isthmus of Panama is as vivid as any movie; we see the flecks of dandruff in Mary Booth’s hair.A long ago teacher of mine said that there can be greater suspense in knowing what’s going to happen than in not knowing. (Think of the 1975 movie The Hindenburg.) Booth confirms that: Since we know about the story’s grim conclusion, there’s tension on every page, even when the characters are farming, riding, or visiting Niagara Falls. I knew nothing about the Booth family beyond being vaguely aware that the Edwin Booth Theater in New York was named for a relative of the most infamous Booth. Now I know that the patriarch was Junious Booth, himself a famous actor in his day, and Edwin was John W.’s brother. That still leaves another eight siblings to talk about, since Junious and Mary Booth had ten children, six of whom survived to adulthood.What’s most fascinating is how closely knit the family was. Various siblings often lived together, and Edwin rescued the family financially. Two other brothers, June and John W., went on the stage, and the three brothers once performed together. So how does what happened happen? If we knew that, maybe we could prevent it happening again. And again. And again....more

title: Wellness
author: Hill, Nathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: *The Nix* was one of my favorite books of 2016. I listened to it in on CD (remember those?) and I’ll stop for a special “wow…just wow” for Ari Fliakos*The Nix* was one of my favorite books of 2016. I listened to it in on CD (remember those?) and I’ll stop for a special “wow…just wow” for Ari Fliakos, the sole narrator, who created a distinct voice for each of many (many) characters, from self-satisfied high school teacher to Norwegian immigrant. Best. Narrator. Ever.I went old school with Wellness, thanks to receiving a free copy from NetGalley. It’s a little less epic in scope, but the same way that *The Iliad* is less epic than *The Odyssey.*Jack Baker and Elizabeth Augustine meet in Chicago as college students. They come from opposite ends of the unhappy childhood spectrum: She, the daughter of old, corrupt money, and he, the son of Nebraska farmers, living out bleak lives on a bleak landscape. (Note: the “bleakness” here is a judgment call from this er, who is herself a “coastal,” if not necessarily “elite,” and prejudiced against the Flyover.) Jack believes he and Elizabeth are soulmates, fated to be together; his belief will be tested in years to come, but Wellness is in large part about the nature of belief itself.Twenty years on, Jack and Elizabeth are living, in some ways, ordinary middle-class lives, working, raising a son, and looking forward to when they can move into their “forever home,” a condo to be built in a new building.But Hill’s gift (I’m tempted to say “genius,” but the term gets overused – let’s put that a temporary hold on that one) is zeroing in on what we many of us deal with every day, from helicopter moms to Facebook junkies to juice cleanses, exposing both the hilarity and the humanity.Wellness never reads as satire, though – just really good storytelling. ...more

review: I fear I’m neither smart nor patient enough to fully enjoy a book of this type. I kept wanting the story to cohere in a more traditional, yes, HollywoI fear I’m neither smart nor patient enough to fully enjoy a book of this type. I kept wanting the story to cohere in a more traditional, yes, Hollywood-network sitcom way. And why are there interspersions of an unseen voice saying “Maybe I am”? Oh, wait, I think that’s our heroine talking to herself. However, even I couldn’t dodge the talent behind the elliptical story. In between readings, the sound of Levy’s writing stayed with me, narrating my own world with her authority and intelligence.Thanks to NetGalley for an opportunity to challenge myself a little with this unusual novel....more

title: Afterword
author: Schuyler, Nina*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this book. That’s not very specific, is it? Well, let me start by saying that I’m familiar with Ms. Schuyler’s books on “stunning sentences,” I loved this book. That’s not very specific, is it? Well, let me start by saying that I’m familiar with Ms. Schuyler’s books on “stunning sentences,” so I was expecting an eloquently written novel, and this is indeed a most eloquently written novel. The stunning sentences never get in the way, though, of a tight plot and an original story. Virginia, 76 now, lives with Haru, an AI program she built based on the math professor who tutored her when she was a teen. Haru fills her every emotional need. But in classic “Frankenstein’s monster” form, he’s evolved beyond what she can control.Anything else I say might diminish the joy of peeling back the layers of Virginia’s and Haru’s stories. So I’ll shut up. It goes without saying that this exploration of Artificial Intelligence is fascinating and timely. Thank you to Edelweiss and Clash books for an advance reader copy....more

title: Playing with Myself
author: Rainbow, Randy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Do you grok Randy Rainbow? Gurl, where have you been? Open your laptop and go to YouTube – NOW!I am not a celebrity junkie. I don’t care who’s marriedDo you grok Randy Rainbow? Gurl, where have you been? Open your laptop and go to YouTube – NOW!I am not a celebrity junkie. I don’t care who’s married, or divorced, or how many children they have. In fact, I stay away from such news, because if I admire an artist, I don’t want to find out that they’re jerks IRL. I am a fan of musical theater, though, and I love Randy Rainbow’s videos, in which he creates new lyrics for Broadway tunes, so I took a chance on *Playing,* even though I risked learning that James Corden is a secret pickpocket.Come to find out that Mr. Rainbow only has praise for everyone. (A little suspiciously so, but maybe that’s me. I don’t like nearly as many people as Randy does.) He even became friends with Anthony Scaramucci. As Mr. Rainbow concludes from that episode, “Life is weird.”The book is, in part, a true memoir: Rainbow describes a problematic childhood (with the name “Randy Rainbow,” his parents might as well have written “please bully me” on his birth certificate), but never with self-pity or bitterness. I particularly appreciated his loving portrayals of the women in his life, beginning with his mother and grandmother. He also details the labor-intensive process of putting together his latter-day, highly polished videos. It’s even harder than it looks, and it looks hard.Extra points for his occasional use of Yiddish, including one word that most non-Jews will have to look up.Thank you to #NetGalley and #StMartinsPress for an advance copy in exchange for an honest . I was honestly thrilled with it....more

review: I *loved* this book, and I'm a tough sell. It combined the best of literary and commercial fiction: fine writing, fast pace, a gripping story, an origI *loved* this book, and I'm a tough sell. It combined the best of literary and commercial fiction: fine writing, fast pace, a gripping story, an original premise--oh, and a setting unfamiliar to most American/UK readers: Lagos, Nigeria.As of this writing, there are over 20,000 s, so I won't weigh you, the reader, down with plot summary. Nor will I read all 20K existing s so as to avoid repetition. I mean, I still have to clean the cat boxes.I will only say that among the many layers here is the complicated bond between sisters, when fate has distributed gifts unevenly and unfairly, yet, to paraphrase the lyrics of the Captain and Tennille song, "love keeps them together."I'm sorry that I can't identify when I started or finished. I didn't "stay up all night." Donna don't do that no more. Actually, did I ever? Yes, when I was 13 and read *1984.* I was hoping there would be a happy ending. Still waiting....more

review: Thank you to Net Galley for an advance copy.I read Mr. Clegg's *Did You Ever Have a Family,* and came away impressed and moved. This novel follows mucThank you to Net Galley for an advance copy.I read Mr. Clegg's *Did You Ever Have a Family,* and came away impressed and moved. This novel follows much the same format, for lack of a more elegant word: many characters, a lot of backstory and a few secrets. Clegg's writing is elegant, and his insight into complex relationships fascinating. We meet most of the main characters when they're in late middle-age, and it's poignant to share their experiences of looking back, and evaluating (or reevaluating) their lives.For many readers this is more than enough. It isn't for me. I need to want to know what happens next, and through most of *Day* I wasn't all that curious. The title itself sums it up: At the end of the day, it will all come together, and you'll know what you want to know. In *Family,* there was enough suspense to keep me going, but here it was too long a wait. ...more

author: Shaffer, Mary Ann

review: An epistolary novel about a little-known aspect of WWII (okay, little known to *me*--am I the last to find out?): that the Germans occupied the ChanneAn epistolary novel about a little-known aspect of WWII (okay, little known to *me*--am I the last to find out?): that the Germans occupied the Channel Islands, British "Crown dependencies," for most of the war, after the British declared them "open," that is, undefended. I like epistolary novels: they honor the tradition of the early novels that were written as letters or diary entries. The challenge: write the letters as someone *would* have written them, that is, not spelling out what the recipient of the letter already knows. (Some letters remind me of those one-sided phone calls on TV: "He did what? He robbed a store? With a gun?" It wasn't easy to write letters in those days. You had to ACTUALLY WRITE THEM, usually by hand, and if you made a mistake you had to cross it out. Then you had to find a stamp. And a mailbox! Granted, it was a different time.I'm giving it four stars because, once accepted on those terms, I did enjoy reading this untold story. (Untold to me; see disclaimer above.)...more

review: The Inevitable Witness possesses all the necessary qualities to succeed as a legal procedural: an intricate plot, interesting characters, and a solid The Inevitable Witness possesses all the necessary qualities to succeed as a legal procedural: an intricate plot, interesting characters, and a solid foundation in the workings of the criminal justice system.It stands out for the intelligent writing and the author’s sensitivity to such troubling issues as the three strike rule, the use of jailhouse informants, and the system-within-the-system of the drug trade.The novel opens with the poignantly-described death of a policeman, which is all the more poignant because the dude who’s buying it turns out to have been a jerk.Read it for the plot; remember it for its insight....more

title: City of Thieves
author: Benioff, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Instructors of creative writing will urge, "Put your character in jeopardy." As with any oft-repeated saying, it sounds a bit trite. Trite, but still Instructors of creative writing will urge, "Put your character in jeopardy." As with any oft-repeated saying, it sounds a bit trite. Trite, but still true, and Benioff puts his protagonist, the hapless Lev, in historic jeopardy by placing him in Leningrad during the infamous WWII siege. After Lev is arrested the Man in Charge (okay, I forget his rank, and no, I can't go back to the book because a very possessive person "loaned" it to me and stood over my shoulder while I read so that he could snatch it back) promises to let him go if he and his accidental comrade Kolya can score the dozen eggs necessary for making a cake for his daughter's wedding.These are the ingredients (hahahaha) for a not-quite-hero's journey that's gripping throughout. There are mass quantities of novels about WWII and recently 2-3 bestsellers that give us the viewpoint of German civilians; this is the first that *I've* read about a Russian civilian (and a Jewish one, at that). Yes, the ingredients are there but any good cook and any good writer knows that it takes talent to put those ingredients together. I don't know what kind of cook Benioff is; he sure is one talented writer....more

(Or in this case, what's on a shelf?)*The Book Thief* has an original premise (you already know that it's narrated by Death), and looks at an unfamiliar part of very familiar territory: the Second World War: civilian life in Germany. Liesel Meminger, the eponymous heroine, comes of age in a working-class town in Germany during the Third Reich--not one of humanity's finest hours.I can't add anything to what other ers have contributed. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: *The Whites* was a unique experience for me.i began listening to it on CD in the car, which is how I consume many--okay, probably most books. I soon f*The Whites* was a unique experience for me.i began listening to it on CD in the car, which is how I consume many--okay, probably most books. I soon found myself rewinding frequently, though, so as to fully appreciate Brandt/Price's writing. The next thing I knew--poof! I had downloaded the e-version so that I could take my time with its lyrical prose.Combining such good writing with an adequately violent story is an accomplishment. I stopped short of the full 5 since the steam of that story gave out its last puff a little early.Worst kept publishing secret: Harry Brandt is Richard Price's nom de cop writing. "Richard Price" is a literary name, evocative of Richard Ford, among others. And "Harry" makes us think of Harry Bosch, of course. Then there's "Brandt" as in "brand name." H'm. I would have chosen something less likely to be misspelled....more

title: Max's Diamonds
author: Greenfield, Jay
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was wary of another book about the Holocaust, even though three of my favorite books from the last ten years have been Holocaust-related (Hope: A TrI was wary of another book about the Holocaust, even though three of my favorite books from the last ten years have been Holocaust-related (Hope: A Tragedy; City of Women; The Book Thief--some day I'll  them, or at least add them to my shelf).Max's Diamonds is post-Holocaust and deals with its effects on the next generation. I imagine that there have been other novels about survivor guilt, but I haven't read them. I read this one, and I'm glad I did.Again, of greatest interest to me was the close look at how the children and relatives of victims and survivors have to reconcile their own, privileged lives (simply being alive is a privilege) against the backdrop of one of history's most unfathomable horrors.There's no pedantry here, though. The plot is as intricately woven as a rag rug. No spoilers: I'll only say that the protagonist is Paul (ne Peretz) and the diamonds of the title are the concrete legacy of the Holocaust that he metaphorically carries with him through this beautifully-written novel....more

title: Bettyville: A Memoir
author: Hodgman, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the book that got me back onto my much-neglected Goodreads account. A leeetle slow to start --but beware the book that opens with cataclysmic This is the book that got me back onto my much-neglected Goodreads account. A leeetle slow to start --but beware the book that opens with cataclysmic events: Where to go from there? And spare me the post-Apocalyptic landscape. We'll get there soon enough.*Bettyville* describes a pre-Apocalyptic world, but one that seems bleak enough to a city girl (we're talking about ME now). The idea that one has to drive G-d knows how many hours just to get to St. Louis (ST. LOUIS??) fills me with dread. WHERE IS STARBUCKS?It isn't clear, in Hodgman's memoir, whether Starbucks has come to Paris, Missouri yet. What is clear is that Wal-Mart dealt the fatal blow to small towns across America, where the family-owned farms and businesses are far less common than meth labs. Hodgman's own grandmother's house has become a meth lab and the site of a homicide. Other features common to dying small towns are dying churches and even an elderly, and thus dying, population. This small town's name is Paris. You couldn't make that up....more

title: The Goldfinch
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Yes, me and 5 billion others have read this book, and I can only justify clogging the Information Superhighway because I didn't "read" it -- I listeneYes, me and 5 billion others have read this book, and I can only justify clogging the Information Superhighway because I didn't "read" it -- I listened to the audio version, which a friend so generously gave me as a holiday gift.I loved the book, but I'm sure that my enjoyment was enhanced by David Pittu's performance. He is the single best narrator I've heard in a decade of listening to recorded books. Pittu could mimic any accent with authority, and brings the novel's best character, Boris, to brilliant life. He even made a very convincing female. (That's a compliment, Mr. Pittu!)The book could have been shorter by as much as a third, but when you're reading *or* listening to a good book, what's the hurry? Also, I was pretty darn impressed with Ms. Tartt's knowledge of such a wide array of subjects as antiques, the streets of Amsterdam, the art world -- and of course, the effects of Narcam on a heroin addict....more

review: In an unspecified, yet not-too-distant future, most diseases can be cured -- by harvesting the organs of clones created and raised for that sole purpoIn an unspecified, yet not-too-distant future, most diseases can be cured -- by harvesting the organs of clones created and raised for that sole purpose.The medical niceties are left to our imagination. What we know is that the children raised for this purpose are real people with real problems, the biggest of which isn't necessarily how to escape their adulthood which will be cut short once they've given up a little too much of their insides.It's a brilliant concept, and Ishiguro handles it with his characteristic understatement. I stopped short of giving this book a 5-star rating only because there was a little too much middle-school drama among the growing children. I hear about that enough at home....more

title: Sister Mine
author: O'Dell, Tawni*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Shae-Lynn Penrose is as hard and gritty as the coal her father once mined from the earth, until that earth swallowed him up in an explosion. She's beeShae-Lynn Penrose is as hard and gritty as the coal her father once mined from the earth, until that earth swallowed him up in an explosion. She's been a single mom, a D.C. cop, and now she's the owner of her small town's sole taxi cab.Author Tawni O'Dell grabbed me with Shae-Lynn's voice from the first sentence, and by page 3 I was deep in the story when I learned that the sister Shae-Lynn has thought dead these many years might still alive. From then on the shocks keep coming like the first warning signs of another mine collapse.This is the first book I've picked up in a long, long time that kept me entertained while nourishing me in equal measure. *Sister Mine* is funny, especially in its crackling dialogue and through Shae-Lynn's wry observations, while it also provides a fresh look at an aspect of American life that gets little exposure: the world of a small mining town. I enjoyed reading about men who take pride in doing their jobs well. I'm not ready to go down a shaft myself yet (I suffer from claustrophobia), but it was good to see the other side, so to speak, of a profession that's not real high on the prestige scale. Seeing that while following Shae-Lynn's humorous, amorous, yet redemtive adventures kept me glued to the futon so that I finished the book almost one sitting....more

title: The Yiddish Policemen's Union
author: Chabon, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You don't have to be Jewish... But you'd miss a lot. In fact, you'll miss a lot unless you remember your parents or grandparents dropping some YiddishYou don't have to be Jewish... But you'd miss a lot. In fact, you'll miss a lot unless you remember your parents or grandparents dropping some Yiddish words. It seems to me that Chabon took a risky career move with this book, but I admire him all the more for that, and the writing, if possible, is even better than his Pulitzer Prize-winning *Kavalier and Clay.* *Yiddish Policeman* combines alternative history (a la Philip Roth's recent *The Plot Against America*) with noir dectective fiction and throws in a little Isaac Bashevis Singer. The sheer chutzpah of his attempt is awe-inspiring and the results are everything I would have hoped. The Yiddish detective in question is Meyer Landsman, a character strictly in the tradition of Philip Marlowe and Sam Spade, except that this cop is living in an imaginary Jewish settlement in the Alaskan panhandle, a temporary refuge for Jews to escape the Nazis. Where many an interested reader might get lost is in the Yiddish puns and Jewish history not well-known to a new, assimiliated generation, let alone non-Jews.In Chabon's world the state of Israel was never established and soon this frozen tundra, too, will be pulled out from under their community -- the rich subculture that Hitler did, for all intents and purposes, annihilate. I wasn't thrilled with some of Chabon's portrayals either of these Jews or their history: in the first place, many are thugs, and in the second, winning the War of Independence is one of the greatest moments in our history. But a writer has to write without worrying about offending his or her audience -- or what's a First Amendment for?...more

title: Bel Canto
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I finally got around to reading this book, which has been recommended to me for many years by well-regarded friends. I kept postponing it because the I finally got around to reading this book, which has been recommended to me for many years by well-regarded friends. I kept postponing it because the premise seemed so off-putting: a gathering of elite international guests are taken hostage in an unnamed banana republic (a small South or Central American country, not the store). Yet once I resolved to get past the grim set-up I was swept away by the author's subtle, inventive and ambitious tale of the Stockholm Syndrome run amok as guerrilas and prisoners work out a way of living together over a period of months while trapped in the vice president's mansion. The book is remarkably (and happily, in my view)apolitical; the story is all about human nature and how it transcends language and culture. The common ground that does bring this unlikely group together is music, and although I prefer the middle-brow Broadway musical form to the more refined opera that touches these souls, still I could feel the passion behind the passion. The book starts surprisingly slowly, considering how many assault weapons are involved, and there are side trips into various characters' pasts that will bore some. But I'm very glad I finally got it off the shelf; I'm a better person for having read it, if not ready to run for office....more

title: A Thousand Splendid Suns
author: Hosseini, Khaled*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Hasseini has the kind of magical storyteller's voice that can make the tale of a trip to the grocery store compelling. His prose is elegant but straigHasseini has the kind of magical storyteller's voice that can make the tale of a trip to the grocery store compelling. His prose is elegant but straightforward and never slows the action (one of my pet peeves about so much literary fiction that ers *kvell* about).*A Thousand Splendid Suns* covers the recent turbulent decades in Afghanistan, beginning before the Soviet invasion. No journalist, not even one conductucting interviews with people who have lived through those times, and no photographer, not even one willing to show body parts dangling from trees, can convey the uncertainty and hardship of those times, or the human drive to find small pleasures where they might hide, the way a good novelist such as Hasseini can. And his book is where I feel I've gained the most understanding into this country and its people.Hasseini's work has been called melodramatic but when told by an intelligent writer, and when I supported by complex characters, I LIKE good melodrama. I cared about these fictional people and what happened to them. I miss them now that they're gone from my life....more
